column1: RB1_SNP;0.0061510075354559;RB1;"RB TRANSCRIPTIONAL COREPRESSOR 1; RB1";live;"Dryja et al. (1984) cloned DNA fragments from chromosome 13. Three of these identified RFLPs from region 13q12-q22

column1: Friend et al. (1986) isolated a cDNA that detects a chromosomal segment having the properties of the gene at the retinoblastoma locus. The gene was found to be expressed in many tumor types
column2: but no RNA transcript was found in retinoblastomas or osteosarcomas. The locus spanned at least 70 kb of DNA. Friend et al. (1986) started with a 1.5 kb DNA sequence which could detect deletions involving 13q14 in 3 of 37 retinoblastomas. They then used chromosome walking techniques to isolate and map 30 kb of surrounding genomic DNA. One of the single-copy fragments recognized a DNA sequence in the mouse genome and also in human chromosome 13. The conservation of this DNA sequence between mouse and humans suggested that the cloned fragment contained a coding exon of a gene. Therefore
column3: they tested the ability of this fragment to hybridize to RNA derived from retinoblastoma cells and from human retinal cells. They found that indeed it recognized a 4.7-kb RNA transcript in the retinal cell line but that this transcript was not detectable in 4 retinoblastomas.

column1: As outlined by Cavenee (1986)
column2: when the cDNA described by Friend et al. (1986) was used as a probe to screen RNA samples from different tumor types
column3: it was shown to hybridize to all of those tested except retinoblastomas and retinoblastoma-associated osteosarcomas. Furthermore
column4: use of this cDNA to analyze the genomic structure of its homologous locus in 50 retinoblastomas or associated osteosarcomas showed that about 30% had somatically altered genomic loci. These alterations took the form of fragments of altered mobility (suggesting gene rearrangements)
column5: underrepresented fragments (suggesting heterozygous deletions)
column6: and missing fragments (suggesting homozygous deletions). Since one of the homozygous deletions was entirely contained within the genomic locus homologous to the cDNA probe
column7: it was suggested that this expressed gene was indeed the RB1 gene.

column1: Dryja et al. (1986) isolated a cDNA fragment derived from human retinal mRNA that detected a locus within 13q14 that is often deleted in retinoblastoma.

Lee et al. (1987) prepared a rabbit antiserum against the RB protein studied by Horsthemke et al. (1987) and showed that it was present in all cell lines expressing normal RB mRNA but was not detected in 5 retinoblastoma cell lines. The RB protein can be metabolically labeled with (32)P-phosphoric acid
column2: indicating that it is a phosphoprotein. Biochemical fractionation and immunofluorescence studies demonstrated that most of the protein is located in the nucleus. Furthermore
column3: the protein was retained by and could be eluted from DNA-cellulose columns
column4: suggesting a DNA binding activity.

column9: and in other tumors such as neuroblastoma and medulloblastoma. The sequence of cDNA clones indicated a hypothetical protein of 816 amino acids.

column2: NONRECEPTOR-TYPE
column3: 11; PTPN11";live;"The protein-tyrosine phosphatases are a highly pleomorphic set of molecules that have a role in regulating the responses of eukaryotic cells to extracellular signals (Dechert et al.
column4: 1995). They achieve this by regulating the phosphotyrosine content of specific intracellular proteins. (1995) noted that the noncatalytic domain shows a striking degree of sequence heterogeneity. In general
column5: however

SH2 domains enable the binding of these SH2 domain-containing PTPases to specific phosphotyrosine residues within protein sequences. The first mammalian SH2 domain-containing PTPase identified was PTP1C (PTPN6; 176883). column1: FLT3_INS;0.0055227085645575;FLT3;"FMS-RELATED TYROSINE KINASE 3; FLT3";live;"The growth factor receptor tyrosine kinase family comprises several classes with distinct structural features. Ullrich and Schlessinger (1990) distinguished 4 classes. One class is represented by the ERBB family (164870). A second class includes dimeric receptors such as the insulin receptor as well as several protooncogenes such as MET (164860) and ROS (165020). A third class is characterized by the presence of 5 immunoglobulin-like domains in the extracellular region and by the interruption of the catalytic domain in 2 parts by a specific hydrophilic 'interkinase' sequence of variable length. This class includes the protooncogene FMS
column2: which encodes the CSF1 receptor (164770)
column3: and KIT (164920)
column4: which corresponds to the 'white spotting' locus in the mouse
column5: as well as 2 PDGF receptor genes (173490
column6: 173410) and FLT1 (165070). A fourth class is represented by the fibroblast growth factor receptors encoded by FLG (FLT2; 136350) and BEK (176943). These receptors have strong sequence similarities to the products of the third class but possess only 3 immunoglobulin-like domains in the extracellular region and a short kinase insert in the intracellular domain. column1: <Subhead> BRAG1: A Spurious 'BCL2-related' Gene

Das et al. (1996) reported the isolation and molecular characterization of a novel Bcl2-related cDNA from a human glioma. They designated the gene BRAG1 for 'brain related apoptosis gene.' They gene showed extensive homology to the BCL2 family of genes. The gene was expressed in normal brain as a 4.5-kb transcript and as a 1.8-kb transcript in human gliomas
column2: which suggested to the authors that it may be rearranged in these tumors. The open reading frame of the BRAG1 gene encoded a protein of 31 kD. Using a bacterial expression vector

The zinc fingers contain sequence elements that place the GLI gene product among the Kruppel (Kr) family of zinc finger proteins (see 165230). (The German word 'Kruppel' means 'cripple' or 'dwarf.') Kr encodes a chromatin-associated phosphoprotein that contains 5 zinc fingers with a consensus sequence connecting the histidine of 1 finger to the cysteine of the next. column1: AKAP9_SNP;0.002382087503481;AKAP9;"A-KINASE ANCHOR PROTEIN 9; AKAP9";live;"Proper synaptic function requires accurate localization of appropriate ion channels and neurotransmitter receptors to the postsynaptic site. column2: Lin et al. (1998) isolated human brain cDNAs encoding a novel protein. The presumed full-length coding sequence encodes a predicted 1
column3: 642-amino acid protein containing many long coiled-coil regions throughout its length. Due to its coiled-coil structure
column4: the authors named the protein 'yotiao
column5: ' after a popular Chinese breakfast food consisting of long strands of fried dough. The interaction of yotiao with NR1 is dependent upon the presence of the 37-amino acid region in the C-terminal tail of NR1 that is encoded by the alternatively spliced C1 exon cassette of NR1. Northern blot analysis of human tissues detected an 11-kb yotiao transcript that was expressed abundantly in skeletal muscle and pancreas
column6: to a lesser degree in heart and placenta
column7: and modestly in brain. Immunohistochemical experiments indicated that yotiao is expressed in a somatodendritic pattern in neurons throughout the rat brain

column10: and cerebellum. The authors demonstrated that yotiao and NR1 are colocalized in rat brain. Yotiao is predominantly located at the neuromuscular junction in rat skeletal muscle. Biochemical studies showed that yotiao fractionates with cytoskeleton-associated proteins and with the postsynaptic density. Lin et al. (1998) concluded that yotiao is an NR1-binding protein that is potentially involved in the cytoskeletal attachment of NMDA receptors.

column1: The SET domain is a highly conserved
column2: approximately 150-amino acid motif implicated in the modulation of chromatin structure. It was originally identified as part of a larger conserved region present in the Drosophila Trithorax protein and was subsequently identified in the Drosophila Su(var)3-9 and 'Enhancer of zeste' proteins
column3: from which the acronym SET is derived. Studies have suggested that the SET domain may be a signature of proteins that modulate transcriptionally active or repressed chromatin states through chromatin remodeling activities. In the course of searching sequence databases for proteins containing SET domains
column4: Harte et al. (1999) identified the SETDB1 sequence. They determined that SETDB1 has a C-terminal SET domain that is well-conserved except that it contains a 347-amino acid insertion between its most highly conserved regions. The authors found that the C. elegans YNCA gene product is highly similar to SETDB1 and also contains a bifurcated SET domain.

column1: Gene duplication and domain accretion are thought to be the major mechanism for the emergence of novel genes during evolution. Genomic sequence analysis has demonstrated extensive amplification events during the evolution of higher primates. Paulding et al. (2003) reported that the USP6 oncogene is derived from the chimeric fusion of 2 genes
column2: USP32 (607740) and TBC1D3 (607741). USP32 is an ancient highly conserved gene
column3: whereas TBC1D3 is derived from a recent segmental duplication that is absent in most other mammals and shows rapid amplification and dispersal through the primate lineage. The chimeric gene USP6 exists only in the hominoid lineage of primates and arose as recently as 21 to 33 million years ago
column4: after proliferation of the TBC1D3 segmental duplication in the primate lineage. Paulding et al. (2003) determined that the full-length USP6 gene encodes a 1
column5: 406-amino acid protein. Amino acids 1 to 496 are derived from TBC1D3 and encompass a TBC domain. Amino acids 501 to 1406 are derived from USP32 and encompass a ubiquitin-specific protease domain. In contrast to the broad expression patterns of USP32 and TBC1D3
column6: RT-PCR analysis showed that expression of USP6 is testis-specific
column7: a pattern proposed for genes implicated in the emergence of reproductive barriers. The authors concluded that the sudden emergence of chimeric proteins
column8: such as that encoded by USP6
column9: may have contributed to hominoid speciation.";tre locus first isolated nih cells transfected human ewing sarcoma dna nakamura huebner found locus discontinuous human cells composed major column1: SLC34A2_DEL;0.0016514657612691;SLC34A2;"SOLUTE CARRIER FAMILY 34 (SODIUM/PHOSPHATE COTRANSPORTER)
column2: MEMBER 2; SLC34A2";live;"Inorganic phosphate absorption from the small intestine and reabsorption from the renal tubule play key roles in the control of inorganic phosphate metabolism and the maintenance of phosphate homeostasis. A number of sodium-dependent phosphate transporters have been identified. Although functionally related
column3: these phosphate transporters are structurally distinct and can be broadly grouped into 3 subtypes based on sequence identity. Type 1 transporters
column4: such as NPT1 (SLC17A1; 182308)
column5: are found mainly in kidney and do not appear to be regulated by dietary phosphate levels. Type 2 transporters can be subdivided into 2 groups based on sequence similarity and tissue distribution. One group
column6: which includes NaPi3 (SLC34A1; 182309)
column7: consists of transporters that are found almost exclusively in the renal proximal tubule
column8: whereas the second group consists of transporters that are more widely distributed. Type 3 transporters can also function as membrane receptors for primate retroviruses. By searching an EST database for cDNAs that show sequence similarity to NaPi3
column9: Feild et al. (1999) identified a human small intestine cDNA encoding the novel phosphate transporter SLC34A2
column10: which they named NaPi3B. They isolated a full-length SLC34A2 cDNA from both human small intestine and lung cDNAs. The deduced 690-amino acid SLC34A2 protein is a type 2 phosphate transporter. It contains 8 predicted transmembrane domains and a cysteine-rich N-terminal region. SLC34A2 shares 78% amino acid identity with the mouse sodium-dependent phosphate transporter IIb. Functional studies showed that SLC34A2 is a sodium-dependent phosphate transporter that is strongly sensitive to pH
column11: with phosphate uptake increased at more acidic pH. Northern blot analysis detected a 4.2-kb SLC34A2 transcript in several human tissues of epithelial origin; kidney also contained high levels of a 2.4-kb transcript. SLC34A2 was most abundantly expressed in lung
